reviewText: Only 2 cartoons on here are not currently on DVD, but they're all good ones! All are directed by Chuck Jones.1. Fast and Furry-Ous (1949; first appearance of Road Runner/Coyote)2. Gee Whiz-z-z (1955; well-known for the classic Bat-Man gag)3. Operation: Rabbit (1952; Bugs Bunny and Wile E's first pairing)4. Hook, Line, and Stinker (1958; horrible canned music in this one by John Seely)5. Zip N' Snort (1961)6. Ready, Woolen, and Able (1960; Ralph and Sam)7. Beep Beep (1952)8. To Beep or Not to Beep (1963; great, except it's all reused footage)

reviewText: The Road Runner and Wile E. Coyote Looney Tunes, in my opinion, are the best cartoons ever made. THE CLASSIC CHASE includes my favorites of all of them. The last one, TO BEEP OR NOT TO BEEP, is my favorite Road Runner cartoon ever made. The best gag is when Wile E. tries to catch Road Runner in a noose is the best gag. FAST AND FURRY-OUS, the first Road Runner cartoon, is one of the best ones. It has to be the fastest paced cartoon I've ever seen. The end was great. The only complaint I have is that none of the cartoons on these 24 Karat gold tapes are restored. All of them have their original TV prints. FAST AND FURRY-OUS really needs to be restored. The print of ZOOM AND BORED is also not restored on A SALUTE TO CHUCK JONES. Just to let you know, if you have the STARS OF SPACE JAM and CHARIOTS OF FUR videos, this collection isn't worth the money. You get cruddier prints here, and 7 out of 8 cartoons are on those tapes. Still, this video might be cheaper than buying the other two videos if you want to save money. This is worth buying!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Throughout his career in animation, Chuck Jones created an unique bundle of characters. Wile E. Coyote was based upon Chuck Jones himself. This collection, as part of Warner Brothers Golden Jubilee 24 Karat Collection, displays unique chases and humorous laughter. The duo of the Coyote and Road Runner, began in Fast and Furry-ous, in 1948. It had worked so well for Chuck Jones, that he was able to stretch Wile E. Coyote further. He even went up against Bugs Bunny, in Operation Rabbit. The first of 5 cartoons he would go after Bugs. The Coyote also spun off to the characters Sam Sheepdog, and Ralph Wolf. Ready, Woolen and Able, displays the similar knock off for mutton, instead of bird. There is no doubt that Chuck Jones created the most unique duo of characters ever. And this was the very first collection to the continuing chase of today. Beep Beep!! Wile E. Coyote Vs. Road Runner The Classic Chase is an real treat. I love it.

reviewText: The videotape contains eight cartoons. All are in color. The image quality for all of the cartoons is excellent, in terms of clarity and definition and lack of any defects. Each cartoon begins with a list of credits, and the listed names include Mel Blanc, famed for his cartoon voices, and Carl Stalling, famed for his musical compositions.I bought this compilation for two reasons. First, in the past couple of years, I made 30 trips to the deserts of southern California, for example, to Joshua Tree National Park, Anza Borrego State Park, Vasquez Rocks County Park, and Death Valley. Rabbits were in abundance, and on every one of these trips I saw from one to four rabbits during the course of my day of exploration. The exception was Death Valley trips, where I never saw any rabbits. I saw roadrunners and only one of these parks, namely, at the southern half of Anza Borrego State Park. And I saw a coyote only once, and this was during one of my 18 visits to Joshua Tree National Park.At any rate, the roadrunner cartoons take place in a fictional location that combines the buttes of Monument Valley in Arizona, the arches found at specific locations in Utah, e.g., Arches National Park or Natural Bridges National Monument, and the saguaro cactuses of southern Arizona. Two of the cartoons in this collection have nice representations of the scenery, but the other cartoons have stone formations that are too stylized, and coloration that is too offbeat, for example, a green-colored sky.The second reason why I bought this compilation was as follows. A patent lawyer at work recommended the roadrunner cartoons, as an example of the process of inventing. In all of the cartoons that feature Wile E. Coyote, it is the case that he tries one invention after the other, in attempts to capture the roadrunner or to capture the rabbit (Bugs Bunny). The roadrunner cartoons focus on various novel inventions that are used by the coyote to trap the roadrunner or the rabbit. In one of the cartoons, WILE E. COYOTE is shown to be the inventor of a patent on a device for massaging bumps on the head. I liked the scene showing WILE E. COYOTE using his invention to treat the bump on his head. The device massages a large bump caused by a 20-ton boulder falling on the coyote's head.These cartoons are famed for their depiction of competitions between the coyote and roadrunner, and here there is no dialogue, except for occasional written dialogue where the coyote and roadrunner hold hand-written signs with English writing. However, in one cartoon, a rabbit (Bugs Bunny) replaces the roadrunner. In this cartoon, both of the characters talk in English.The coyote always loses in these competitions, and the viewer is "treated" to at last 20 scenes in this collection of cartoons where the coyote is bonked on the head by a 20-ton boulder. More entertaining, are scenes where the coyote plummets off of a 2-mile high cliff and lands with a splat at the bottom of a narrow canyon. I enjoyed the perspective resulting from the skilled hand of the cartoonist, in depicting the tall canyons.In the cartoons on this compilation, there were several scenes that were genuinely clever or entertaining. In one scene, the coyote paints an entrance to a tunnel on the side of the cliff, hoping to trick the roadrunner into running into the cliff and getting knocked out. The roadrunner gets tricked, but what happens is that the roadrunner actually runs through the tunnel and out the distant end. The coyote, more interested in his own stomach that in reality, immediately follows the roadrunner through the painted tunnel, but the coyote bonks himself on the head, because the tunnel is just painted on the surface of a cliff. In another cartoon, an extended episode features a multi-component Rube Goldberg type invention, with several clever intermediate steps, where the result is that Coyote gets shot by a cannon.For parents who feel that a child can be suitably be entertained by watching a 20-ton boulder landing dozens of different times on the head of a coyote, then this compilation is fine. However, was a little disappointed by a couple of cartoons, where the landscapes are overly stylized and where the features of the landscape are barely recognizable as buttes or canyons, and where the cartoon includes strange colors, such as a green sky. Another disappointment is that this compilation contains one episode that is about sheep dogs, and no coyote and no roadrunner. The sheep dog episode is called, READY, WOOLEN, AND ABLE. At any rate, I find the cartoon containing the Rube Goldberg device to be one of the best episodes on this product.I have another recommendation. What I recommend and prefer, is THE FLINTSTONES cartoons, because these cartoons also include many novel inventions, as is the case with the roadrunner cartoons, and because, like the roadrunner cartoons, it is the case that the FLINTSTONES also takes place in a primitive stone-age environment.
summary: Not so entertaining, but a fine chunk of an obscure corner of American culture
